segments.text: So, after a disastrous couple of years,
has Apple finally admitted defeat? This
week, Apple and Google announced a major
multi-year partnership, which will see
Google's Gemini power Apple's AI
features, including a major new Siri
upgrade that is due for release later
this year. So, in this video, we're
going to take a look at what this might
mean for Apple, for Google, and also for
the wider AI market, too. Plus, OpenAI
has revealed a new health product, but
do you really trust that company with
your health data? And a major new
release from Claude sees the company try
to build upon its billiondoll cash cow,
Claude Cord, by adapting it to
non-technical use cases. So, we got all
that coming up in this slightly revamped
version of the briefing. And as always,
if you do enjoy the channel, then hit
the subscribe and the like button. So
this week, Apple and Google formally
announced a new partnership that will
see Gemini become Apple's model for
powering products like Siri. In a post
from Google, they say that after careful
evaluation, Apple determined that
Google's AI technology provides the most
capable foundation for Apple models and
that it's excited about the new
innovative experiences that it will
unlock for Apple users. So, if we strip
away some of the PR spin here, it looks
as though Apple has finally admitted
what we all suspected after their
botched 2024 launch, and that is that
right now at least, it can't build its
own foundational AI models at a
competitive scale. For a company that
has spent decades building this
narrative that it makes everything
better in house, particularly after the
impressive development of their M series
MacBook chips, they seem to have
publicly acknowledged that their AI
efforts are insufficiently capable to
compete. Apple has been bleeding AI
talent over the past few months. And as
always, the clock is ticking down to the
next WWDC. And so it's understandable
why they might do this because Apple
needs something impressive to announce
this year. For Apple in 2026, this makes
strategic sense. Why should they bother
wasting even more time and money
building something inhouse when other
companies have already built the
technology they need? In many ways, this
echoes Apple's previous decisions with
search, maps, and Intel chips. This is a
defeat only in the sense that they were
originally trying to do it all
themselves, but they were failing at it.
Admitting defeat and partnering with
Google is probably a much smarter
approach for now, at least. For Google,
it's pretty much a win-win as they're
set to bag an extra $1 billion in
revenue, which is pretty much a drop in
the ocean to those guys. But more
importantly, they get to prove to the
market that they are now the leading AI
model maker. The company's stock price
is up 7% at the time of recording, which
is hardly surprising. But not everyone
is thrilled. Elon Musk has called the
news an unreasonable concentration of
power for Google, particularly given
that they already have Android and
Chrome. Competition authorities may be
inclined to agree. For OpenAI, though,
this is a potential body blow. Back in
2024, Apple chose to integrate its AI
features with chat GPT, but this
decision seems to reflect the perception
that Gemini is now the model to beat.
It's also worth remembering that since
2024, Johnny IV has teamed up with Sam
Alman to develop a new piece of
hardware. And whilst this is pure
speculation on my behalf, perhaps this
defection by Johnny Iive to OpenAI also
left a bitter taste in the mouth of
Apple execs. The partnership gives Apple
the ability to speed up the development
of new AI features by piggybacking on
top of Google's foundational models,
which buys itself some time to develop
its own models. Apple Intelligence was
definitely a failure, but was that
because the technology was awful, or was
it because of a failure of product
market fit? The question that I keep
thinking about is, do users even want
these powerful AI features baked into
their operating systems like Apple
previously did with Apple intelligence,
or do they prefer AI assistants to live
inside some sort of dedicated app? With
this new partnership with Google, Apple
now has some time to find out, and it'll
be fascinating to see what Apple cooks
up for Apple Intelligence 2.0. zero.
What do you think? Will Apple build a
new set of AI features that users
actually want to use this time around or
has the damage already been done even
with the help of Google? Let me know in
the comments below. And speaking of some
new features that users may potentially
not want, Google itself has announced a
new AI inbox which gives users a radical
alternative to a traditional inbox. So
this is an AI inbox that sits above the
original inbox inside the Gmail
navigation. So you can see from this
screenshot that this is a clear
hierarchal decision that suggests that
Google thinks that this should take
precedence over a traditional inbox. The
UI consists of suggested to-do items
from the day and summaries from your
most important emails. At the same time,
Google has confirmed that is making
other AI features like suggested
replies, AI overviews, and help me write
tools all free to users after previously
only being available as paid features.
Google's VP of product for Gmail posted
a video on LinkedIn outlining these
features and he says that Gmail is now
in its Gemini era. So, this AI inbox
certainly feels like a potentially
helpful feature. But what happens if the
daily overview misses something
important? On one hand, I can see how
Google's AI inbox makes strategic sense.
Your email contains your receipts, your
relationships, your commitments, your
entire transactional history. So, it is
arguably more valuable than your search
history for understanding intent and
action. Google has had this data for
over 20 years, but up until this point,
it hasn't really extracted much
intelligence from it beyond spam
filtering, but on the other hand, I
don't think I'd ever feel particularly
comfortable relying on a summarized
version of my inbox to bring me up to
speed with my most important items for
the day. I'm sure I'd find AI inbox
useful and maybe perhaps even too
useful, but I just worry that I become
reliant on it and then miss some
important emails. Google execs will be
starting the year happy about the
performance of Gemini products. A new
data released this week seems to justify
that. According to this freshly
published data from similar web, chat
GBT has lost a further 4% in AI traffic
share while Google has increased its
share to over 20%. Now these stats are
only for the web and so it's worth
caveating that because as we know lots
of people access AI assistance through
mobile apps. So I'm guessing the data is
a lot different when you factor in
mobile devices. But they do put OpenAI's
pre Christmas code red into more
context. And speaking of chat GPT,
they've kicked off their 2026 with their
first major launch of the year by
launching a new subproduct called chat
GPT health. Based on the UI, you can see
that health is a separate section within
chat GPT that you access from the
sidebar menu. It has its own
conversation history, its own memories,
and its own connected apps that are all
walled off from regular Chat GPT apps.
And in the launch notes, they mention a
framework called the Healthbench
framework, which emphasizes the clinical
safety behind all this. And it looks as
though this is the groundwork for
selling chat GBT into healthcare
providers. OpenAI CEO of apps Fiji
shared her own experience with using the
app for health and she says that 230
million users are currently asking it
about health related questions. But the
question for OpenAI is whether users
themselves trust the company with their
own health data. OpenAI is hardly the
most trusted company in the world, at
least in tech circles. But perhaps the
wider public just won't care so much.
Elsewhere this week, Claude has unveiled
a major new product. It's calling
cowwork, which it describes as Claude
code for the rest of your work. So, the
background here is that Anthropic
noticed that developers were essentially
using Claude Code for repurposing
non-coding tasks. That's things like
vacation research, slide decks, email
cleanup, organizing photos, and so on.
And Claude Code's co-creator, Boris
Churnney, said that users were doing all
sorts of non-coding work. So, Anthropic
did what good product teams do. listened
to the shadow use case and built an
offering around it. The implementation
of this makes it much easier to use. So
you don't have to go through the
terminal. You can instead use a desktop
app and it also integrates with existing
connectors. So things like notion,
Gmail, Asana and so on. Anthropic
engineers reportedly built this entire
product in approximately 10 days and of
course they use claude code to do it.
Some of the use cases outlined by
anthropic in cowwork include things like
creating files, crunching data, making
prototypes, and organizing files. So in
this example, you give Claude access to
a folder on your computer, and then
Claude will organize those files into a
spreadsheet. These use cases were
already available in Claude, but by
repackaging this offering into a less
intimidating tool that lives in the
terminal, Claude Code is hoping that it
it can build upon the $1 billion revenue
run rate that it achieved back in
December. And while we're on the topic
of Claude, Claude projects is also a
feature that's often overshadowed by
other tools like Claude Code and the
newly released Skills, which is now set
to become an open standard for the
industry. What many people don't realize
though is that you can actually combine
projects with features like Skills to
build powerful reusable systems at work.
And in this week's knowledge series over
on Substack, I explain how you can use
Claw projects to monitor the health of
your business. I talk you through how
you can use Claude projects to monitor
health indications like user data, value
proposition, new X health, and more. So,
if you're interested in learning more
about how you might be able to use
Claude projects at work, then check out
that over on Substack. Now, let's move
on to some data and trends for the week.
And we'll start with the story of
Tailwind. So, this is a story. This is
an insight into the unintended economic
consequences of using AI agents. The CSS
framework Tailwind says that it has laid
off 75% of its engineering team simply
because it became too popular with AI
agents. So essentially this destroyed
its primary upsell channel which is
where users would visit their
documentation to find out more about
their commercial offerings and then
upgrade to a paid package. The docs were
the only way for people to find out
about their commercial offerings. But AI
agents don't read docs in the same way
as humans do and ultimately they don't
care about commercial upsells. The
company says that traffic to docs is
down 40% and revenue is down a massive
80%. So this is shaping up to be a
brutal but fascinating insight into the
second order consequences of AI agent
adoption. This is definitely something
for product teams who are reliant on
similar upsell mechanics to consider.
And continuing the theme of AI agents,
which is a pretty heavy focus for this
week, a new study shows that engineers
actually do enjoy working with AI agents
for coding with some important caveats.
So in this study, enjoyment was measured
on a six-point scale, which compared
coding with agents versus coding
without. The average score overall was
5.1, which is actually really high,
indicating that developers generally
felt pleased or extremely pleased. But
there was one important caveat. Working
with AI agents was enjoyable so long as
engineers remained in control and were
able to thoroughly review its output.
So, this is a fascinating new study that
looks at how engineers actually work
with AI agents and more importantly what
they think about it. So, check that one
out. I'll put the link to that in the
description. And 2026 looks to be the
year that the adoption of AI agents
starts to explode. So, McKenzie's global
manager said last week that by the end
of the year, he expects the company to
have as many personalized AI agents as
employees, but that the overall
headcount of the company won't
necessarily decrease. So if you put this
into context, McKenzie actually has over
40,000 employees. So technically that is
over 40,000 AI agents that are set to be
deployed into production this year. So
instead of reducing their overall
employee headcount, the company is
reconfiguring its employee composition.
But it looks like some work is getting
automated hard while other work, in this
case client relationships and judgments
calls is becoming more valuable. And
finally this week, if you are interested
in learning more about what the hottest
jobs in the world are, LinkedIn has
published its new jobs on the rise
report, which is definitely worth a
read. Perhaps unsurprisingly, AI
engineers have taken the top spot with
AI consultants and strategists in
second, and most of the people in the
role in that role transitioned into it
from product management. So, I'll put
the link into the description to that if
you want to read more. And on that note,
thanks very much for listening and
watching. I'll be back next week with
another briefing.

In a post from Google, they say that after careful evaluation, Apple determined that Google's AI technology provides the most capable foundation for Apple models and that it's excited about the new innovative experiences that it will unlock for Apple users. So, if we strip away some of the PR spin here, it looks as though Apple has finally admitted what we all suspected after their botched 2024 launch, and that is that right now at least, it can't build its own foundational AI models at a competitive scale. For a company that has spent decades building this narrative that it makes everything better in house, particularly after the impressive development of their M series MacBook chips, they seem to have publicly acknowledged that their AI efforts are insufficiently capable to compete.
